climbs.name: You Know There Is A Ladder

content.description: The angled crack is a good jug. Start as low as you can.
content.protection: You don't have to have crash pads, but they aren't a bad idea.
content.location: Begin just to the right of the ladder on the south side.

content.description: Look under the rock for the beginning food hold. It's sort of hard to find but is very useful.
content.protection: A soft "mat" is built in, but if you've got a crash pad and want to bring it, that's not a bad idea.
content.location: This is on the south side of the rock just to the left of the thumb.

content.description: Start as low as you can to make it harder and harder.
content.protection: None is necessary, but you can always use crash pads.
content.location: This is the farthest left on the north side.

content.description: Start at the top, and descend the south side. Climb through the hands then go back up the north side.
content.protection: Crash pads are not a bad idea but not crucial with the ground as soft as it is.

climbs.name: Between A Thumb And A Pointer Finger

content.description: Start between the thumb and the middle finger. It is really easy to do, just a simple mantel to the top is all.
content.protection: Crash pads aren't necessary but can be useful.
content.location: This is between the thumb and pointer finger on the south side.

content.description: This has lots of pockets. If you over think your moves, it gets harder. Kids have put acorns in some of the pockets, and they are a pain to get out.
content.protection: Crash pads aren't necessary but can be useful.
content.location: This is the farthest right on the north side.

pathTokens: Denver Metropolitan Area Bouldering and Buildering
